liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Five of Gaza's main hospitals have erected tents to accommodate patients, according to the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Among them, says the UN's latest report, is Shifa Hospital in Gaza City, which is "treating some 5,000 patients, significantly over its capacity of 700 patients". "[This is] in addition to approximately 45,000 [displaced people] taking refuge within and around the hospital," the report said. "These and other hospitals are on the brink of collapse due to the shortage of electricity, medicine, equipment and specialised personnel. "Large numbers of patients are being treated on the ground given there are not enough hospital beds."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gaza hospital built to treat 700 now treating 5,000, says UN

children.content: Five of Gaza's main hospitals have erected tents to accommodate patients, according to the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.
Among them, says the UN's latest report, is Shifa Hospital in Gaza City, which is "treating some 5,000 patients, significantly over its capacity of 700 patients".
"[This is] in addition to approximately 45,000 [displaced people] taking refuge within and around the hospital," the report said.
"These and other hospitals are on the brink of collapse due to the shortage of electricity, medicine, equipment and specialised personnel.
"Large numbers of patients are being treated on the ground given there are not enough hospital beds."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As of October 23, 12 hospitals and 46 primary care clinics in Gaza "are no longer functioning", the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says. The group's latest report says 34 health care facilities and 24 ambulances have been affected since October 7. "All hospitals are implementing emergency contingency plans that affect functioning and access to health care," the report said. It added the extent of damage "sustained by educational facilities and other civilian infrastructure" is a growing concern. "As of October 21, 206 educational facilities have been affected, including at least 29 [United Nations] schools," they said. "Eight of these schools were used as emergency shelters for [displaced people], with one of them being directly hit." There are now 590,000 people staying in 150 UN shelters, 101,500 sheltering in churches and hospitals, and almost 71,999 in 67 non-UN schools, according to the UN's estimate.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 12 hospitals 'no longer functioning' and hundreds of schools damaged

children.content: As of October 23, 12 hospitals and 46 primary care clinics in Gaza "are no longer functioning", the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says.
The group's latest report says 34 health care facilities and 24 ambulances have been affected since October 7.
"All hospitals are implementing emergency contingency plans that affect functioning and access to health care," the report said.
It added the extent of damage "sustained by educational facilities and other civilian infrastructure" is a growing concern.
"As of October 21, 206 educational facilities have been affected, including at least 29 [United Nations] schools," they said.
"Eight of these schools were used as emergency shelters for [displaced people], with one of them being directly hit."
There are now 590,000 people staying in 150 UN shelters, 101,500 sheltering in churches and hospitals, and almost 71,999 in 67 non-UN schools, according to the UN's estimate.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli bombardments across the Gaza Strip have intensified "three-fold" compared to previous days, says the latest UN update. The UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says the deadliest attacks in the last 24 hours included "several airstrikes on residential buildings in Jabalia Refugee Camp" and in northern Gaza. "Furthermore, in the last 24 hours, two UNRWA installations, one in Al Bureij camp and the other in Nuseirat in the middle area, sustained collateral damage due to airstrikes in the surrounding areas of these facilities," the report said. The estimated death toll among Palestines has now surpassed 5,000 according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's air strikes in Gaza intensify 'three-fold', says UN

children.content: Israeli bombardments across the Gaza Strip have intensified "three-fold" compared to previous days, says the latest UN update.

The UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says the deadliest attacks in the last 24 hours included "several airstrikes on residential buildings in Jabalia Refugee Camp" and in northern Gaza.

"Furthermore, in the last 24 hours, two UNRWA installations, one in Al Bureij camp and the other in Nuseirat in the middle area, sustained collateral damage due to airstrikes in the surrounding areas of these facilities," the report said.
The estimated death toll among Palestines has now surpassed 5,000 according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health.

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Australian stocks edge up, while the trade union will force a de facto ban on engineered stone if the government fails to act to protect workers from the deadly lung disease Silicosis. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX edges up, ACTU to boycott engineered stone, Zip surges on earnings prospect

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by National Health Reporter Elise Worthington The nation’s peak trade union body says it will force a de facto ban on engineered stone if the government fails to act to protect workers from the deadly lung disease Silicosis. The Australian Council of Trade Unions says its members, including the CFMEU, which represents Stonemasons, and the Maritime Union of Australia, will band together to prevent the product from being brought through ports or transported by union members to construction sites across the country next year. Engineered stone contains high levels of silica which can cause incurable lung disease if workers inhale dust while cutting the material. The ACTU says as many as 1 in 4 stonemasons that work with engineered stone have been diagnosed with silicosis. Federal, State and Territory Work Health and Safety Ministers will meet on Friday to discuss a report by Safe Work Australia which has investigated banning the product. A spokesperson for the Federal Workplace Relations Minister Tony Burke says the Commonwealth will be asking the meeting to agree to publicly release the report. “The Albanese Government believes no one should ever contract a terminal illness simply because they’ve turned up to work” the spokesperson added.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unions to boycott engineered stone

children.content: Reporting by National Health Reporter Elise Worthington
The nation’s peak trade union body says it will force a de facto ban on engineered stone if the government fails to act to protect workers from the deadly lung disease Silicosis.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions says its members, including the CFMEU, which represents Stonemasons, and the Maritime Union of Australia, will band together to prevent the product from being brought through ports or transported by union members to construction sites across the country next year.

Engineered stone contains high levels of silica which can cause incurable lung disease if workers inhale dust while cutting the material. The ACTU says as many as 1 in 4 stonemasons that work with engineered stone have been diagnosed with silicosis.
Federal, State and Territory Work Health and Safety Ministers will meet on Friday to discuss a report by Safe Work Australia which has investigated banning the product.
A spokesperson for the Federal Workplace Relations Minister Tony Burke says the Commonwealth will be asking the meeting to agree to publicly release the report.
“The Albanese Government believes no one should ever contract a terminal illness simply because they’ve turned up to work” the spokesperson added.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Zip Co has jumped nearly 11 per cent after the buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) company returned to profitability earlier than projected in the first quarter of fiscal 2024 as domestic operations improved. Shares in the company rose to $0.33, the highest price since mid-September. Zip, Australia's biggest standalone BNPL service provider, said it returned to cash earnings before taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBTDA) profitability in the first quarter of fiscal 2024, ahead of its prior guidance for the first half. Owing to the strong performance of its domestic and New Zealand businesses and continued strength in the US total transaction volumes, Zip upgraded its forecast with an aim to touch cash EBTDA profitability for FY24 from a prior projection for the second half of fiscal 2024. "Zip continues to expect to achieve a positive Group cash EBTDA result for 2H24 and following a particularly strong start to the year, Zip now expects to achieve a positive Group cash EBTDA result for FY24," CEO and Managing Director Cynthia Scott said. The company logged a total transaction volume (TTV) of $2.3 billion for the first quarter, an increase of 11 per cent over last year. Group revenue came in at $204.4 million, up 31.9 per cent from a year earlier. US bad debts continued to perform well with monthly cohort loss rates of about 1.3 per cent of TTV, below the target range of 1.5-2.0 per cent, Zip added.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Zip shares jump on the prospect of returning to profitability

children.content: Zip Co has jumped nearly 11 per cent after the buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) company returned to profitability earlier than projected in the first quarter of fiscal 2024 as domestic operations improved.
Shares in the company rose to $0.33, the highest price since mid-September.

Zip, Australia's biggest standalone BNPL service provider, said it returned to cash earnings before taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBTDA) profitability in the first quarter of fiscal 2024, ahead of its prior guidance for the first half.

Owing to the strong performance of its domestic and New Zealand businesses and continued strength in the US total transaction volumes, Zip upgraded its forecast with an aim to touch cash EBTDA profitability for FY24 from a prior projection for the second half of fiscal 2024.

"Zip continues to expect to achieve a positive Group cash EBTDA result for 2H24 and following a particularly strong start to the year, Zip now expects to achieve a positive Group cash EBTDA result for FY24," CEO and Managing Director Cynthia Scott said.

The company logged a total transaction volume (TTV) of $2.3 billion for the first quarter, an increase of 11 per cent over last year. Group revenue came in at $204.4 million, up 31.9 per cent from a year earlier.
US bad debts continued to perform well with monthly cohort loss rates of about 1.3 per cent of TTV, below the target range of 1.5-2.0 per cent, Zip added.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket has turned flat at lunchtime. Investors are closely watching the developments in the Middle East after Israeli aircraft struck southern Lebanon and Israeli troops and Palestinians clashed in the occupied West Bank. Market participants are also awaiting a slew of data from the United States later in the week, including third-quarter gross domestic product numbers and personal consumption expenditures report, to assess the economic strength of the country. Back home, financial stocks rose 0.2 per cent. Mining stocks gained 0.1 per cent after a three-day slide. BHP and Rio Tinto climbed 0.1 per cent and 0.4 per cent, respectively. Energy stocks jumped 0.3 per cent, with Woodside Energy and Santos rising 0.1 per cent and 0.7 per cent, respectively. Technology stocks lost 0.1 per cent after four consecutive sessions of losses. Gold stocks fell 0.7 per cent, heading for their worst day since Oct. 3. Shares of Northern Star Resources rose 0.1 per cent. Among individual stocks, shares of Zip advanced more than 11 per cent after the buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) firm returned to profitability in the first quarter of fiscal 2024, earlier than previously projected. Shares of Core Lithium and Pilbara Minerals climbed 3.8 per cent and 3.9 per cent, respectively, to be among the top gainers in the benchmark index.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX flat at lunch time

children.content: The Australian sharemarket has turned flat at lunchtime.
Investors are closely watching the developments in the Middle East after Israeli aircraft struck southern Lebanon and Israeli troops and Palestinians clashed in the occupied West Bank.

Market participants are also awaiting a slew of data from the United States later in the week, including third-quarter gross domestic product numbers and personal consumption expenditures report, to assess the economic strength of the country.
Back home, financial stocks rose 0.2 per cent.
Mining stocks gained 0.1 per cent after a three-day slide. BHP and Rio Tinto climbed 0.1 per cent and 0.4 per cent, respectively.
Energy stocks jumped 0.3 per cent, with Woodside Energy and Santos rising 0.1 per cent and 0.7 per cent, respectively.
Technology stocks lost 0.1 per cent after four consecutive sessions of losses.
Gold stocks fell 0.7 per cent, heading for their worst day since Oct. 3. Shares of Northern Star Resources rose 0.1 per cent.

Among individual stocks, shares of Zip advanced more than 11 per cent after the buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) firm returned to profitability in the first quarter of fiscal 2024, earlier than previously projected.
Shares of Core Lithium and Pilbara Minerals climbed 3.8 per cent and 3.9 per cent, respectively, to be among the top gainers in the benchmark index.
